comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Looks like Markethill or maybe Slane. Definitely seems familiar.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Could it be Rathdrum Co. Wicklow? maps.google.com/maps?q=Rathdrum,+Wicklow,+Ireland&hl=...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: There was a Barry's Hotel there, home to architect Thomas Lowey from 1914 to 1919 www.dia.ie/architects/view/3241

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: John Barry is listed as a shopkeeper in the 1911 census but he has 7 boarders so could have become a hotelier by 1915 www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai003654570/ and Owen Jones Comerford is listed as a Flour and Indian Meal Miller www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai003654254/

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The hotel isn't marked on the 1908 OS Map but that would fit with the 1911 census entry maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,718922,688337,7,9

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: This run of houses matches exactly with the photo above - it's gotta be Rathdrum. maps.google.com/maps?q=Rathdrum,+Wicklow,+Ireland&hl=...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Streetview: Comerford's on the right!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] I think you got it.  Well done!

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Wow - I didn't spot that! There's continuity for you!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Yes, well done [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03]! The NIAH has an entry for Comerfords which references the doorway at right of this shot: The entrance consists of a panelled timber door with four-pane rectangular fanlight all encased by slender engaged Tuscan-like columns and entablature with cornice.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Huzzah! Thanks a million all, and especially you [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03]  ... Rathdrum it is!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: *bows humbly*

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Lambretta Club of Ireland: Evening Herald, 7th April 1955. A most enjoyable run to Rathdrum via Kilmacanogue and Laragh last sunday. There were 22 members and 17 scooters, tea was at Barry's Hotel in Rathdrum. So the Hotel does not give any help on a latest date. Since Comerford's is still there, it obviously doesn't!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Admiring the mega-zoomy-whatsit-thingumy for this photo on the NLI website - catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000290423 . Is that new, or am I just slow?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The building just beyond the Hotel looks like a Post Office. The 1908 map shows the post office where the Hotel is in this shot. So the post office may have moved along the street when the Hotel was built.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I think it must be - the signage, the group of people outside and the proximity to the 1908 location all point that way.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] You're not at all slow! It was unleashed on an unsuspecting world with no fanfare whatsoever only yesterday. I share an office with the boffiny genius behind it, and he's very pleased with the moniker mega-zoomy-whatsit-thingumy for it as Image Viewer is very boring! Perhaps we'll just shorten it to Mega-Zoomy?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I was just clicking around to see how much of the archive had been megazoomified. So from this one, clicking on Similar Items I found OCO_25 which I knew, then OCO_125 which I knew, then OCO_121 ditto.

Looking at past Fergus O'Connors in the Flickr stream, I went to OCO_84 (Kilnap Viaduct) and from similar items, I found another at Kilnap (OCO_124) a Sandymount at OCO_338 a familiar church art OCO_138 another Dodder one at OCO_108.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Yes, well I tried it on a clatter of old Limerick photos to see if I could find my long lost fortune but to no avail as they've not been Zoomyed yet!

comment.author: 52433458@N00
comment._content: Hello,  I have just seen this shot,  i live in rathdrum,  amazing to think that Comerforts shop on the right is still here, and still is a drapery shop,   beside comerforts is Jacobs pub,   Barrys hotel i remember my mam and dad talking about,  the post ofice in Rathdrum is way the other side of town,  not in this shot at all,  unless back then the post office was here,  the road at the center of shot in the distance is the road to Laragh / Glendalough  ,  John

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/svadee] Hello John! Thanks a million for getting in touch. Always lovely to hear from a local, and if you should find out from any older residents about where the post office was back then, we'd be delighted to hear about it...

Maybe that premises across the road was just an ordinary shop at the time?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 52433458@N00
comment._content: Hello,  Yes,  i have posted a link to this photo for somebody else to look at,  on the left where the man with arms folded is,  until recently was a bookies,  and the where you think that post office is,  is now a car show rooms,  Is it possible all the people in the photo are waiting on a bus or something,  i see a guy down the street heading that way, with a suitcase or something like that,  maybe all the people waiting on a bus  !!    Just a thought ,  anyway,  will be back with more,     John

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/svadee] I suppose it's absolutely possible that there could have been a bus due. Thanks a lot for passing on the photo...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
